Selective hydrogenation of carbon dioxide to light hydrocarbons over ZnZrO X /H-MFI composite catalyst with long-term stability Shohei Harada Investigation Visualization Writing – original draft a Duanxing Li Resources b Kenta Iyoki Conceptualization Methodology b Masaru Ogura Supervision a ⁎ a Institute of Industrial Science, The University of Tokyo, 4-6-1 Komaba, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 153-8505, Japan Institute of Industrial Science, The University of Tokyo 4-6-1 Komaba, Meguro-ku Tokyo 153-8505 Japan Institute of Industrial Science, The University of Tokyo, 4–6-1 Komaba, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 153–8505, Japan b Department of Chemical System Engineering, The University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-8656, Japan Department of Chemical System Engineering, The University of Tokyo 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku Tokyo 113-8656 Japan Department of Chemical System Engineering, The University of Tokyo, 7–3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113–8656, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. This study investigates the catalytic performance of composite catalyst composed of ZnZrO X and H-zeolite for hydrogenation of CO2 to light hydrocarbons (C2–4). It is shown that deactivation of composite catalyst was caused by ion exchange of Zn2+ and/or coke and differs between various zeolite structures. When ZnZrO X and H-MFI were mixed by mortaring, Zn2+ migrated to H-MFI and caused ion exchange of Brønsted acid sites during the reaction, resulting in deactivation. This could be avoided by separating grains of ZnZrO X and zeolite. As for H-MOR, the amount of coke formed during the reaction was large, and coke affected the catalytic activity rather than Zn2+ ion exchange. However, as for H-beta, those two deactivations were observed. The composite catalyst composed of ZnZrO X and H-MFI which were mixed loosely, separating their grains showed a high catalytic activity for 120 h. Therefore, it is a promising catalyst for one-pass catalytic conversion. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CO2 hydrogenation CCUS ZnZrO X Zeolite Deactivation Data Availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Recently, numerous technologies to gain renewable energy have been developed dramatically. These technologies can supply energy to our society based on carbon neutrality. However, it is needed to remove more CO2 than that formed through our normal lives toward net-zero emission of CO2. In the carbon-neutral society, CO2 must be recycled as a C1 feedstock or stored in a deep underground, which is called CO2 capture, utilization and storage (CCUS). CCUS has been globally developed and socially implemented [1–3]. Hydrogenation of CO2 to form hydrocarbons is one of the most important reactions in the processes under CCUS, and lots of research have been carried out to develop a catalyst effective for the reaction [4–7]. Hydrogenation of CO2 provides us three products [4,8]: Carbon monoxide (CO) formed by Eq. (1) is a feedstock of Fischer-Tropsh synthesis along with hydrogen to form liquid fuels and lubricants [9]; Methanol (CH3OH) formed by Eq. (2) is converted to light hydrocarbons such as ethylene and propylene through Methanol-to-Hydrocarbons (MTH) reaction [10,11]; Methane (CH4) formed by Eq. (3) is less reactive than CO and CH3OH due to inert C(sp3)−H bond [12–14]. Selective transformation of CO2 to a useful material, especially CO and CH3OH, through hydrogenation is critical for recycle and reuse of CO2 [4,15,16]. Thus, enormous challenges have been done to improve the selectivity to CO and CH3OH, and to overcome the limitation of equilibrium conversion of CO2. (1) CO 2 + H 2 ⇄ CO + H 2 O , ∆ r H 298 O = 41 kJ / mol (2) CO 2 + 3 H 2 ⇄ C H 3 OH + H 2 O , ∆ r H 298 O = − 49.5 kJ / mol (3) CO 2 + 4 H 2 ⇄ C H 4 + 2 H 2 O , ∆ r H 298 O = − 165 kJ / mol Industrial production of CH3OH using Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 and the further conversion of CH3OH to C2+ hydrocarbons using zeolites (MTH) have been developed [17–19]. Product distribution of hydrocarbons from CO2 hydrogenation via CH3OH can be controlled by zeolite structure [20,21]. Thus, this route, with CH3OH as the intermediate, is promising for selective production of hydrocarbons via CO2 hydrogenation. In contrast to the conventional catalysts, a new catalyst using metal oxides such as ZnZrO X (ZZO), GaZrO X , and In2O3 showed activity for CH3OH synthesis at high temperatures (> 300 °C) [22–26]. Thanks to the catalytic activity of those metal oxides at high temperatures, the composite of metal oxide and zeolite has been used for one-pass production of hydrocarbons through CO2 hydrogenation [27–30]. The combination of ZZO and zeolite is the promising candidate among tested samples for the reaction due to the high catalytic activity of ZZO for CH3OH synthesis [26,31]. In this study, the composite catalysts composed of ZZO and some typical zeolites were prepared by a physically mixing method. The catalytic activity test for one-pass hydrocarbon synthesis at a high pressure (3 MPa) is conducted to find a key to scale up a CH3OH-mediated hydrocarbon production by preparing various combinations of ZZO and zeolite. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Zinc-loaded zirconia, ZZO, was prepared by an impregnation method of ZrO2 (JRC-ZRO-5, Catalysis Society of Japan) with an aqueous solution of Zn(NO3)2･6 H2O (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corporation), which was described in the literature [25]. Obtained powder was dried at 110 °C for 12 h, followed by calcination at 500 °C for 3 h. The atomic ratio of Zn to Zr was set to 0.27 (≒ 20 wt% of ZZO). Following proton-type zeolites were supplied: H-MFI-50 (Si/Al=50, H-MT-100, Mizusawa Industrial Chemicals, Ltd.), H-MFI-200 (Si/Al=200, H-MT-400, Mizusawa Industrial Chemicals, Ltd.), H-MOR-45 (Si/Al=45, JRC-Z-HM90, Catalysis Society of Japan), and H-beta-55 (HSZ-960HOA, FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corporation). The composite catalysts used in this study were prepared by two mixing methods; the composite of ZZO and H-MFI-50 was prepared by mixing with a mortar and pestle, and the weight ratio of ZZO to H-MFI was 1 (g/g). The mixed powder was pressed at 30 MPa to form a disk, and the disk was crushed and sieved to granules with 100–1000 µm in diameter. The sample prepared by this method was denoted as ZZO/H-MFI-50-M. On the other hand, zeolites with 30 wt% SiO2 (Fumed Silica, Sigma-Aldrich) as a binder was pressed, crushed, and sieved. Separately prepared granules of ZZO and zeolite+SiO2 were mixed with the weight ratio of ZZO to zeolites = 1 (g/g). These samples were denoted as ZZO/H-MFI-50-G, ZZO/H-MFI-200-G, ZZO/H-MOR-45-G, and ZZO/H-beta-55-G. 2.2 Characterization An X-ray diffraction (XRD) instrument with Cu Kα radiation, MiniFlex 600 (Rigaku), operated at 40 kV and 15 mA was used to observe crystal phase of catalysts. The XRD patterns were recorded in 2θ range of 10–90 degree using a scanning step of 0.01. Physicochemical properties of catalysts were evaluated by N2 adsorption, QUADRASORB evo (Anton Paar). Surface area of catalysts (SBET) was calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, and their micropore volume (Vmicro) was calculated using the t-plot method. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was used to evaluate acid strength of catalysts. NH3-TPD experiment was performed using BEL-CAT (MicrotracBEL). A catalyst sample (30 mg) was pretreated at 500 °C for 1 h under flowing He and cooled to 100 °C. Then, 5% NH3 (He balanced) was introduced. After dosing NH3 adsorption for 30 min, the sample was heated to 620 °C at the heating rate of 10 K min−1. Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was used to investigate the acid site of zeolite utilizing a FT/IR-4100 (JASCO) spectrometer equipped with a triglycine sulfate detector. The experiment was performed using pyridine as a probe for acidity. Each zeolite powder (40 mg) was pressed at 10 MPa into a 10 mm disks and subjected to the measurement. The catalyst disk was dehydrated at 200 °C for 3 h under evacuation. For the adsorption experiment, pyridine was introduced in a glass cell until the pressure of the vapor phase became constant at room temperature. Thereafter, the cell was evacuated to remove the physically adsorbed and residual gaseous pyridine. Each FT-IR spectrum was recorded after the absorption intensity was stabilized at rt. The amount of coke formed during CO2 hydrogenation was measured by thermogravimetry-differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) utilizing Thermo plus EVO2 (Rigaku). Except for ZZO/H-MFI-50-M, granules of ZZO and zeolite were separated, and each zeolite was heated up to 1000 °C at the heating rate of 5 K min−1under air flow (30 mL min−1). 2.3 Catalytic activity test The catalytic activities for CO2 hydrogenation were evaluated using a high-pressure, fixed-bed flow reactor operated at 350 °C and 3.0 MPa. A catalyst was placed in a stainless-steel reactor (inner diameter=14 mm, length=50 cm). Typically heated to a certain temperature, reactant gas mixture (H2/CO2 =3 (molar ratio), FCO2= 1.2 L h−1) was fed into the reactor. The outlet gas was analyzed using gas chromatographs (GC) equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and with H2 flame ionization detector (FID). Liquid product was analyzed using GC-FID. Gaseous components, namely, H2, CO, CO2, and C1–3 hydrocarbons were detected using GC–TCD, and C4+ hydrocarbons and CH3OH were detected using GC–FID. Conversion and selectivity of each reaction were calculated using Eqs. (4)–(6), and the performance of each catalyst under various reaction conditions was evaluated after CO2 conversion became constant, typically after 72 h. (4) CO 2 conversion = CO 2 in × F in − CO 2 out × F out / CO 2 in × F in × 100 [ % ] (5) CO selectivity = CO out × F out / CO 2 in × F in − CO 2 out × F out × 100 [ % ] (6) Hydrocarbon and methanol composition = i × C i out × F out / ∑ i × C i out × F out × 100 [ % ] * i = the number of carbon 3 Results and Discussion XRD patterns of the catalysts used in this study are illustrated in Fig. 1. In the XRD pattern of ZZO, the diffraction peak derived from (111) plane of ZrO2 appeared around 31 degrees, and peaks derived from ZnO were also observed on the same sample [32,33]. The physicochemical data of ZZO and each zeolite is shown in Table 1. Zeolites are microporous, while ZZO is non-porous. NH3-TPD profiles of the zeolites used in this study were summarized in Fig. 2, in which the h-peak appeared at different temperatures around 290 °C, 310 °C, 330 °C, and 410 °C on H-beta-55, H-MFI-200, H-MFI-50, and H-MOR-45, respectively. This result means that the order of acid strength is beta < MFI < MOR. The catalytic activities of ZZO, ZZO/H-MFI-50-M, and ZZO/H-MFI-50-G are summarized in Tables 2 and 3 and Fig. 3. ZZO showed the constant catalytic activity (CO2 conversion≒13%) for 120 h and products contained only CO and CH3OH (Fig. S1) without forming hydrocarbons at 350 °C. The initial catalytic activity of ZZO/H-MFI-50-M was high (CO2 conversion≒23%), however, as the reaction continued, CO2 conversion decreased. On the contrary, the catalytic activity of ZZO/H-MFI-50-G was stable for 120 h (CO2 conversion≒20%). Comparing the hydrocarbon composition in the gas phase, ZZO/H-MFI-50-M and ZZO/H-MFI-50-G showed the similar composition in the initial period of reaction: more than 70% selectivity to C2–4 hydrocarbons. On the other hand, after 120 h of reaction, the selectivity to C2–4 over ZZO/H-MFI-50-M became lower than those of ZZO/H-MFI-50-G, and the selectivity to CO of ZZO/H-MFI-50-M became as high as that of ZZO (≒80%). From this result, it seems that H-MFI in ZZO/H-MFI-50-M was deactivated during the reaction. Wang et al. reported that Zn2+ ion is migrated to zeolite grain when ZnO and H-zeolite composite catalyst was used, resulting in ion exchange of Zn2+ into a zeolite acid site during CO2 hydrogenation under a reductive atmosphere [34]. The ion exchange alters the catalytic activity of the H-zeolite. In addition to that, high selectivity to C5+ by ZnCrO X /Zn-ZSM-5 was reported by Zhang et al. [35], and they suggested that Zn-ZSM-5 showed a higher selectivity to C5+ than H-ZSM-5 during CO2 hydrogenation. Zn2+ ion exchange might occur under the CO2 hydrogenation conditions used in this study even if zinc is used as the form of ZZO. Fig. 4 shows the NH3-TPD profiles of ZZO/H-MFI-50-M before and after the reaction. It is found that the h-peak of NH3 adsorbed on the strong acid sites of H-MFI became smaller and shifted to lower temperature after the reaction. In addition, considering that the Vmicro of ZZO/H-MFI-50-M decreased from 0.073 cm3 g−1 to 0.067 cm3 g−1 without changing XRD patterns before and after the reaction, protons in H-MFI of ZZO/H-MFI-50-M seems to be ion-exchanged with Zn2+ during the reaction. Given that it has been known that Zn-MFI forms less C3 and C4 through CH3OH dehydration than H-MFI [36–38], decreasing distribution of C2–4 among the gas phase hydrocarbons over ZZO/H-MFI-50-M catalyst is caused by migration of Zn, resulting in the ion exchange of H-MFI by Zn2+. This Zn2+ migration was confirmed by SEM-EDS images (Fig. S2). In the EDS mappings, Zn2+ was observed on the H-MFI surface of spent ZZO/H-MFI-50-G as well as that of ZZO/H-MFI-50-M. Different from ZZO/H-MFI-50-M, ZZO/H-MFI-50-G kept a high hydrocarbon yield and a low CO selectivity for 120 h. The difference between those two catalysts was only their mixing methods of ZZO and zeolite. It has been reported by Gao et al. [39] that the separation of a metal oxide and a zeolite affected the catalytic selectivity of the composite catalyst. In their work, the composite catalyst composed of Indium-doped ZrO2and SAPO-34 (In-Zr/SAPO-34) mixed by mortaring method showed high selectivity to CH4, whereas the composite mixed loosely in a vessel showed high selectivity to C2–4. In-Zr mixed with SAPO-34 by mortaring caused ion exchange of protons with In3+, resulting in a low selectivity to C2–4 with a high selectivity to CH4. In our case, although the hydrocarbon composition gradually changed during 72 h on stream, ZZO/H-MFI-50-G kept its high selectivity to C2–4 (≒70%) in the prolonged reaction (72–120 h), while preventing deactivation. Consequently, separation of ZZO and zeolite grains is critical to attain high selectivity to light hydrocarbons. It should be noted that the catalytic activity of ZZO/H-MFI-50-G kept constant while Zn2+ was migrated on the H-MFI surface. Comparing NH3-TPD profiles of the spent catalysts (Fig. S3), the strong acid sites of H-MFI in ZZO/H-MFI-50-G remains more than those of ZZO/H-MFI-50-M. Therefore, it can be said that by separating ZZO and zeolite migration of Zn2+ are limited, and some portions of strong acid sites of H-MFI in ZZO/H-MFI-50-G keeps its catalytic activity at a certain level. Tables 2 and 3 show the influence of framework Si/Al molar ratio of MFI. Given that olefin/paraffin of the gaseous product was low, ZZO/H-MFI-200-G showed higher selectivity to olefins than ZZO/H-MFI-50-G with a high selectivity to C6+ compounds. This trend between Si/Al molar ratio and product selectivity has been known in MTH reactions using H-ZSM-5 [40,41], where a higher Si/Al gave a higher selectivity for C5+. The trend observed in this study indicated that such trend is also true in the case of CO2 hydrogenation. Figs. 5 and 6 show that zeolite structures also affected the catalytic performance. As for zeolite structure, MOR and beta showed altered product distributions, and at last CO2 conversion was decreased. In the initial period of the reaction (up to 3 h), ZZO/H-MOR-45-G and ZZO/H-beta-55-G showed a higher selectivity to C2–4 (≒90%). This high selectivity to C2–4 was reported by Tada et al. [26], whereas selectivity to liquid and solid products became high as reaction prolonged (Fig. 6). Especially over ZZO/H-beta-55-G, the reactor outlet was clogged by a solid product containing large aromatic molecules (Fig. S4) at around 60 h of the reaction. Moreover, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons were detected in spent H-beta and H-MOR by UV–vis (Fig. S5), whereas little aromatic hydrocarbons were detected in spent H-MOR. This trend indicates that H-MFI has long lifetime thanks to low formation of aromatic hydrocarbons. In the step of MTH, so-called carbon pools in zeolite have a key to high selectivity for C3+ and aromatics, and a smaller pore zeolite tends to form smaller hydrocarbons [42,43]. Thus, MOR and beta which have larger pore sizes than MFI resulted in less C2–4 yields in the long-term reactions. It is noteworthy that over 90% of C4+ products at the initial term were n- and iso-alkanes, and this trend was common in all composite catalysts used in this study. After TOS= 48 h, only ZZO/H-MFI-50-G showed high selectivity to n- and iso-alkanes with low selectivity to aromatic hydrocarbons (<0.1%) due to its specific framework structure. Considering the CO2 conversion in the initial period of the reaction (∼3 h), ZZO/H-MOR-45-G showed highest value and ZZO/H-beta-55-G showed lowest value among the three catalysts tested. This trend seems to comply with acidity of various zeolites. At the dehydration step of CH3OH in MTH reactions, a catalyst with strong acid sites showed a high reaction rate [44,45]. Fu et al. reported that when H-MFI (Si/Al=12.5) was compared to H-FAU (Si/Al=3.9), H-MFI attained a high conversion of CH3OH (around 90%) at 425 K, whereas H-FAU showed a low conversion of CH3OH (around 10%) at the same temperature [45]. It has been known that the hydrophobicity of zeolite also affects the reaction rate [46]. However, the zeolites in this study have a similar value in the Si/Al ratio (around 50), and their hydrophobicity is expected to be similar. Thus, the acid strength of zeolite may cause the difference in CO2 conversion of the initial period of reaction. Considering that CO2 conversion of ZZO/H-MFI-50-G was stable for 120 h, while those of ZZO/H-MOR-45-G and ZZO/H-beta-55-G decreased during the reaction. In NH3-TPD profiles of the composite catalysts ( Fig. 7), acid sites in MFI were not regenerated even on ZZO/H-MFI-50-G, whereas those in MOR and beta were almost fully regenerated by calcination. In addition, MOR and beta showed a large weight loss observed in the catalysts after the reaction compared with MFI as demonstrated in Fig. 8. The weight loss mainly occurred over 400 °C, so that the loss is derived from combustion of carbon deposited on the surface of the used zeolite catalyst [47,48]. This indicates that coke formed during the reaction deactivates ZZO/H-MOR-45-G and ZZO/H-beta-55-G. Pyridine-probe FT-IR analysis was carried out, and the typical spectra are shown in Fig. 9. The peak derived from pyridine adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites (1545 cm−1) [49,50] was hardly observed on MFI and MOR catalysts after the hydrogenation reaction. In contrast, Lewis acid sites (1440–1450 cm−1 and 1580–1600 cm−1) [51] appeared after the reaction. MOR kept the peak derived from ammonia adsorbed on the Brønsted sites (1470 cm−1) as shown in Fig. S6 [52,53]. Since pyridine is unable to enter the 8-membered ring of MOR [54], pyridine adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites of MOR was not observed. In contrast, ammonia adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites of MOR was observed, so that Brønsted acid site remains on MOR after the reaction mostly in the 8-membered ring. Coke formation in MOR might occur prior to Zn2+ migration and ion exchange. These results show that the key factor of deactivation is varied by zeolite structures: ion exchange in MFI, coke formation in MOR, and both in beta, respectively. Therefore, choosing zeolite structures is critical to improve the catalytic performance of the composite catalysts as well as mixing method. 4 Conclusions CO2 hydrogenation using ZZO/H-zeolite composite catalysts was carried out using a fixed-bed flow reactor under a high pressure (3 MPa). By contacting ZZO and MFI zeolite tightly, Zn2+ migrates from ZZO to the zeolite resulting in a rapid deactivation of the composite catalyst. On the other hand, separating those two catalysts helps to keep the catalytic activity for 120 h. In addition to the mixing methods, it was elucidated that zeolite structures also affect the catalytic performance. A zeolite having a strong acid site such as MOR shows a high catalytic activity in the initial period of the reaction. However, in the long-term reaction, MOR resulted in deactivation caused by the coke formed during the reaction. From pyridine- or ammonia-probe FT-IR, Zn2+ migrates to MFI and beta resulting in ion exchange also in the case that ZZO and zeolite were spatially separated, whereas coke formation occurs prior to the ion exchange over the MOR catalyst. Toward the catalyst development based on the composite of ZZO and zeolite, both the mixing method and choosing optimal zeolite structure are critical for CO2 transformation as well as high product selectivity such as C2–4. As a result of this study, MFI is a promising zeolite for one-pass catalytic conversion due to its appropriate micropore system preventing coke formation and adequate acidity for dehydration of CH3OH obtained on ZZO at the same temperature. coredata.dc:description: This study investigates the catalytic performance of composite catalyst composed of ZnZrO X and H-zeolite for hydrogenation of CO2 to light hydrocarbons (C2–4). It is shown that deactivation of composite catalyst was caused by ion exchange of Zn2+ and/or coke and differs between various zeolite structures. When ZnZrO X and H-MFI were mixed by mortaring, Zn2+ migrated to H-MFI and caused ion exchange of Brønsted acid sites during the reaction, resulting in deactivation. This could be avoided by separating grains of ZnZrO X and zeolite. As for H-MOR, the amount of coke formed during the reaction was large, and coke affected the catalytic activity rather than Zn2+ ion exchange. However, as for H-beta, those two deactivations were observed. The composite catalyst composed of ZnZrO X and H-MFI which were mixed loosely, separating their grains showed a high catalytic activity for 120 h. Therefore, it is a promising catalyst for one-pass catalytic conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Selective hydrogenation of carbon dioxide to light hydrocarbons over ZnZrO X /H-MFI composite catalyst with long-term stability
